topic.title: [Desktop Software] Tor Browser for 64-Bit Linux Version 6.0.2_en-US
topic.body: The Tor Browser lets you use Tor on Windows, Mac OS X, or Linux without needing to install any software. It can run off a USB flash drive, comes with a pre-configured web browser to protect your anonymity, and is self-contained (portable).

topic.title: Request for an ISR/ISRTalk vision revision.
topic.body:
I kind of start loosing track of exactly what we are building here and why. 
Could we have a discussion about the aims and goals of ISR and ISRTalk hash database projects? 

Don't get me wrong both projects have my full support (that is why I initiate this discussion).

Some concrete questions:
- What are the benefits of getting the software from ISR instead of the official sites?  
- Why should people trust our collection better than the official source? 
- Who are the target audience of ISR?

topic.title: Ideas about our hash collecting project.
topic.body:
I think we should make the hash collection an independent project. Than we may be able to convince people not interested in ISR to contribute hashes to our collection.

I think creating a kind of web of trust for hashes is a good idea in itself. Probably, there are people who would contribute even if they are not interested in ISR. 

There are important features our collection misses now:
- being clear-cut (we only have a few hashes so far , but it is already quite chaotic)
- being searchable
- being a real database (or at least one that is easy to turn into one)
- being easily able to tell the distribution of hashes of a certain file. 
- having a form that contributors should fill in to submit data (to make the collection as clear-cut as we can)
- having a gazillions of contributors. 
- encouraging everybody to always hash the software they acquire, compare the hash to the official site and/or our database, and of course to contribute the data to our database (even if it differs from the majority of our collection!). 
- a safeguard that our database is not compromised (this is a though but important one, maybe a strong user base and an alert system that makes easy to track changes comparing the Zites version to the users saved versions could be a kind of solution). 

There are some features on http://127.0.0.1:43110/ZeroTorrent.bit/ which we may implement, but we should do that wisely. Simply cloning it and changing IMDB id to SHA256 sum is really fare from a good solution.

topic.title: Adding endorsement links to the ISR list next to the names.
topic.body:
There are other nice collections (based on some important feature of the software, such as security and source openness). For example:
http://127.0.0.1:43110/1J625kWnshbcBk9gE9BdPr4peTeXusRzU8/
https://prism-break.org/en/all/
https://directory.fsf.org/wiki/Main_Page

I think we should put a little icon next to the names in our collection indicating if that software is also endorsed by the other collections.

topic.title: Using (also) IPFS to make the files available.
topic.body: I think IPFS (https://ipfs.io/) has some nice features. I think we should consider the option of using it. I'm not familiar with IPFS, but I think it worth discussing this option.

3_1CSc14JKdGAQJfQsfCLrduhB6zU4oEMwBf.body:
I think we should make as easy to see if a sum is different from the rest as possible.  
Therefore, I think we should have a different topic (or subtopic if there is such a thing) for every file. 
That way all the md5 and sha256 sums in the same thread should be equal.

Here is a simple Bash script that auto generates all the important info (file name, timestamp, source, sha256 and md5 sums) from a download link (you just have to copy paste the outcome in the corresponding topic): [0isrsum.sh](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1MgHVPCE1ve6QfKrgsqCURzRj72HrRWioz/?17VwZEfWSUWb5RHkK9m1odnDdBfvjTL6Cp_2)

4_1CSc14JKdGAQJfQsfCLrduhB6zU4oEMwBf.body:
> [zeroexef](#comment_3_1CSc14JKdGAQJfQsfCLrduhB6zU4oEMwBf): @testset: Your script is great! I think the direct link to the download is a great idea too, as that will show us if somebody got it off github vs official site etc.
> 
> We might need a port to windows if you know what you're doing. Because windows is annoying however, it might need a gui to paste in the web address.

Sorry, I cannot make the gui or the windows porting. 
I'm not a programmer, only know some basic Bash scripting... :-(

> [zeroexef](#comment_7_1CSc14JKdGAQJfQsfCLrduhB6zU4oEMwBf): I think this'll be easier to navigate and find what we're looking for if we keep the same version for all OSes in a single thread. Thoughts?

It depends, what is the purpose of this hash database. 

If the only aim is to get at least 3+ independent verification of the hashes for the [ZeroISR](http://127.0.0.1:43110/12oGb8xBjLYz23CGJxRQyzZ6mGybZokEKt/), then maybe it is better if we have only a few topics (but even then I'm not sure because that way we lose the possibility to automatically compare the hashes we have collected, see below). 

However, if we would like to have an ever growing sha256 and md5 sum database that worth to be checked even if someone downloads the software from somewhere else, then I think it is better if one topic contain only the hashes of one file. That case it is important to have a really easy way to see what is the distribution of the hashes of a file (hopefully it is a trivial distribution and there is only one hash several times).

Of course, if we are aiming to create that it should be also searchable, as for example http://127.0.0.1:43110/ZeroTorrent.bit/. (It would be even better if it were really a database, that is a problem for an other day...)  

Anyway, a great benefit of having a different topic for every file is then it is really easier to check if all the hashes are the same there or not. And if not, it is easier to see what is the distribution of the hashes. 

For example, if all.txt contains all the text of a topic, then the 
`sed -e 's/.*[Mm][Dd]5/md5/' -e '/md5\:/!d' all.txt | tr '[:upper:]' '[:lower:]' | sort`
bash command creates a list of hashes where it is really easy to tell if some of them is different or not. 

Right now applying it to the [The Tor Browser Bundle Thread](http://127.0.0.1:43110/15CmNF5L1murN3UMb4fZMuWJtpq689JRhx/?Topic:1_1CMjV2r4EBpFt8VCcWWZKDysZXPcPExRNN/+Desktop+Software+The+Tor+Browser+Bundle+Thread) the result is:
md5: 4ff8c08394cdb42198b7f2fada600455
md5: d4b74112374b75b38a8174b1d37086fe
md5: d4b74112374b75b38a8174b1d37086fe
md5: d4b74112374b75b38a8174b1d37086fe
md5: d4b74112374b75b38a8174b1d37086fe

Now you can see without any real effort that 1 of the 5 hashes is different from the rest. (Of course, here the reason for the anomaly is that one of the hashes corresponds to the Linux version). However, if they were the hashes of the same file, then it would mean that something fishy is going on so we should collect more data to decide which hash is trustworthy.

Note that, however, even if these 5 hashes corresponded to the same file, it would be dangerous to assume that the single 1 is the wrong and the other 4 is the right, because maybe the source was compromised when we collected the first 4. So the right attitude were not trusting any of them until we have collected more data.

So probably it is better, to have a different topic for every file independently how ambitious our aims are with this database. 

Have I convinced you?

I have improved the data generating script. Now [0isrsum.sh](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1MgHVPCE1ve6QfKrgsqCURzRj72HrRWioz/?17VwZEfWSUWb5RHkK9m1odnDdBfvjTL6Cp_3) works with both links pointing to files and with files that are already downloaded.

I'm not sure how severe this danger is, but in principle if Mallory gets the keys of the [ZeroISR](http://127.0.0.1:43110/12oGb8xBjLYz23CGJxRQyzZ6mGybZokEKt/) and this Zite, then he/she will be able to replace any software on ZeroISR with one containing a malware and replace all the sums here with the ones corresponding his/her software containing a malware, see  [this](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1_17VwZEfWSUWb5RHkK9m1odnDdBfvjTL6Cp/Can+the+owner+of+ZeroTalk+delete+modify+any+content+here) topic. 

What do you think about this security flaw of our project?

> [tkarita](#comment_4_1GervYZoP82e8X1Rgc4wyMkJY2zSsJuq8t): It would be easy to track changes made by specific users based on which files get modified during updates.  Determining who has changed the entire site with a shared private key would probably be much harder.

Is it possible to tell if a modification of a comment was made by the commenter or a owner/signer of the ISRTalk?

By the way, ideally the comments containing hashes should not be deleted or modified ever at all. 
The only reason I can imagine to delete or modify such a comment if it become 100% clear that the hash is wrong. For example, the commenter realizes that he/she summed the wrong file.

Is it possible/difficult to write a program automatically checking if these hash comments of ISRTalk are changed or not? 

It would also be nice if there were a software able to automatically compare the hashes on [ZeroISR](http://127.0.0.1:43110/12oGb8xBjLYz23CGJxRQyzZ6mGybZokEKt/) to corresponding ones here.

Of course, "There is no system but GNU, and Linux is one of its kernels." =)
So I agree the zip file covers all OSes (that is GNU/Linuxes). 
Moreover, it even has a portable exe file for Windows users. 

Still I think the topic title is a bit misleading. Some folks use the OS term in a broader sense and considers other systems as OSes... (For example, the one with the partly-eaten-apple symbol.)

1_1ADB7TdX2fVbTsWBoMe9yBTmVXTbb33b4R.body:
> [zeroexef](#comment_30_1CSc14JKdGAQJfQsfCLrduhB6zU4oEMwBf): Done. Let me know what you guys think.

Nice, but it would be even better if it were in a separated 'Description' drop down. 
Expecting people looking for description to click on the 'Download' drop down is quite strange.

17_1CSc14JKdGAQJfQsfCLrduhB6zU4oEMwBf.body:
This is cute, really. 

From the beginning I couldn't decide if I have joined some naive project initiated by some enthusiastic kids or a really cunning honeypot building of some 'group Malory' as NSA. 

But making "whether we should have 150x150px little avatars" top priority question while the project already has so many deep security/etc. flaws sort of settles the problem... I simply cannot imagine a 'group Mallory' being so extremely tricky...   =)

So here is mine: 

---
testset -- the critic
I mainly help the project with constructive criticism and other ideas.

> [zeroexef](#comment_41_1CSc14JKdGAQJfQsfCLrduhB6zU4oEMwBf): You didn't give me an icon, so I went with the first result of google images. It's horrible. Please help it. It haunts my dreams

Yes, it is quite horrible, but it is good to know that my username has a meaning =)

Let's use the following image instead:
https://pixabay.com/en/detective-searching-man-search-1424831/

I tried to use [NullFolder](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1GrtBsG57kjU2Z3iAQebG9D5c8CRDRLoPj/) to share the svg file, but I was not able to make it work... :-/

Ps: Use https://duckduckgo.com instead of google. It does not track you... and it has some really nice features such as [!bangs](https://duckduckgo.com/bang).

> [imurx](#comment_18_14J8mC3K7k5Ygx22uu9LUzGWnBoDAQdyDo): What do you think about an opened box with a bunch of apps (maybe put the apps we already put)

I think it could symbolize the ISR quite well.

2_17VwZEfWSUWb5RHkK9m1odnDdBfvjTL6Cp.body:
> [zeroexef](#comment_32_1CSc14JKdGAQJfQsfCLrduhB6zU4oEMwBf): 
> 
> The primary aim of ISR is that everyone everywhere will always be able to access important software for their day to day life. 

I like this part. How about stating it on the Zite in a separate first paragraph formulated as:
"Our primary aim is to make important software accessible to everyone everywhere."
?

>This means that if the videolan website dies forever, or for some reason is compromised (think hackers or censorship), there will always be at least one verified genuine installer for VLC on ISR.The secondary reason is more due to the hacker/censorship/NSA sort of thing. We hope (yes, just hope) that the software we all know and love is not compromised at the moment. We can support this hope by the fact the many people across the world are using the same file as us. The reason this makes us feel better is that if, say, the NSA built a backdoor into bitmessage, they likely wouldn't do that for servers outside the US. Instead, they would more likely just redirect US website visitors to their own page, complete with compromised download.This is why the file hashing is important. It tells us that we aren't being sent a fake file (or at least everyone is, but we hope that's less likely).  For all intents and purposes, going to the official site to download might still be a good idea if you are able. Then take that link and cross check the hash against our table.   

This is part is a bit confusing. For example, "the website dies forever" is quite an extreme case. So I'm not sure it is a good idea to use that for illustrating why our collection is useful. I think we should use more everyday situations here as government censorship and MitM/DDoS attacks. Also I'm not sure  VLC is the best example to be used in the illustration. I love VLC, but I'm not sure that is among the most endangered important software.

The secondary reason also rises several questions: 
- Isn't "supporting hope", "makes us feel better", etc. are misleading terms? Mallory and NSA want people "to feel secure". We should want them "to be more secure". See Bruce Schneier's [The security mirage](https://www.ted.com/talks/bruce_schneier/transcript) TED talk.
- Are we more secure yet? (Especially looking us from out side. Can we give any guarantee that we are not 'group Mallory' trying to make people trust and use our software?)
- Can we become more secure than (or at least as secure as) the official source? If yes, how?
- etc.

> [imurx](#comment_16_14J8mC3K7k5Ygx22uu9LUzGWnBoDAQdyDo): I think this is called "essay" you could put it below "Zero ISR Zeronet - Important Software Repository"

I like the idea to put a 1 sentence goal-description in the headline.

5_17VwZEfWSUWb5RHkK9m1odnDdBfvjTL6Cp.body:
Why don't we simply use their favicons? 
https://www.privacytools.io/favicon.ico
https://prism-break.org/assets/ico/favicon.png
https://static.fsf.org/fsforg/img/favicon.ico

4_17VwZEfWSUWb5RHkK9m1odnDdBfvjTL6Cp.body:
> [imurx](#comment_24_14J8mC3K7k5Ygx22uu9LUzGWnBoDAQdyDo): ZeroHCP (Zero Hash Collection Project)or ZeroHCDP (Zero Hash Collection Data Project)

How about ZeroHDP (Zeronet - Hash Database Project), 
ZeroSHD (Zeronet - Software Hash Database) 
or simply ZeroHD (Zeronet - Hash Database)?

> [zeroexef](#comment_46_1CSc14JKdGAQJfQsfCLrduhB6zU4oEMwBf): Here we are. Introducing ZeroHDP - Our new hash database project.http://127.0.0.1:43110/17dtW9szkWFatjPhss8f5r8FVAfh3WEZ7x/

Nice!!! 
I think it still needs several improvements, but it is a good start. 
We should turn this page as "foolproof" as we can... (We should make it at least difficult for users to turn this database (either deliberately or accidentally) into a mess.)  

Can you turn the "submit comment" into a "submit hash data" requiring the user to provide only hash data in different well structured fields (timestamp, filename, source, hash)?

It would also be nice to have some guidelines in the headline explaining the aim and how to add new software to avoid duplicates or ambiguous collections.

Also instead of "Add Hash" it would be better to use "Add New Software" asking enough data (version, platform, 32bit/64bit) to make the file corresponding the software unique. So ideally in one thread we should expect to have the same unique hash collected by plenty of people. [Having two different hashes in one thread should mean that one of the sources is compromised (or that our guidelines were not foolproof enough).]
